text:
She must be the same as I am, Raskolnikov thought. 

“Ah, how I hate the old woman!” 

He strained to think, battling delirium. 

“Poor Lizaveta! Why did she come in?” 

He barely remembered her. 

“Why don’t they weep? Why don’t they moan?” 

Sonia! Gentle Sonia! 

He lost consciousness. 

Twilight fell. 

The moon shone brightly. 

Raskolnikov wandered the streets, mournful and anxious. 

He had a purpose, but it slipped away. 

Suddenly, a man beckoned from across the street. 

Raskolnikov crossed over. 

The man turned and walked away, head hanging. 

“Did he really beckon?” Raskolnikov wondered. 

He hurried to catch up, recognizing him. 

Fear gripped him.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Raskolnikov grapples with his guilt and confusion after committing murder, reflecting on the women he has harmed and feeling a sense of urgency despite forgetting his purpose.
